div.h2: Schools Remain Closed | New 2020 Grad Guidance
div.p: Dear Oregon City School District Students, Families and Staff:

The speed of change during the past few weeks has left all of us feeling unanchored. A little more than three weeks ago, school was still in session, and everyone was beginning to show signs of restlessness in anticipation of a spring break. High school seniors were beginning to use the term "senioritis," and looking forward to many treasured traditions and rites of passage on the way to graduation.

We now know from Governor Kate Brown’s announcement earlier today that schools will be closed for the remainder of the school year. While we understand the health and safety reasons for this directive, we are deeply saddened by the loss. We so looked forward to being together again as a learning community before the summer months.

p.a: Continue reading the full letter from the Superintendent.

hr.p: Dear Oregon City School District Families:

Late last night, the Oregon Department of Education (ODE) sent notice to all Oregon school districts signaling a shift in the state’s approach to continued learning during this unprecedented extended school closure. The new guidance outlines a "distance learning for all" model. The reason for this change, according to state officials, is the real potential that schools could remain closed for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Continue reading the full letter from the Superintendent.
All previous updates from the Superintendent are also available.

News about COVID-19 (Coronavirus) and its encroaching spread raises questions and concerns for everyone. Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses that usually cause mild respiratory illnesses such as the common cold. However, COVID-19 is a new coronavirus that had not been seen in humans before. There is currently one identified case of COVID-19 in Oregon.

p.strong: Oregon City School District is closely monitoring this situation and is in frequent contact with public health authorities.

hr.p: Local school districts are collaborating with the Clackamas Educational Service District and health authorities to stay informed and prepared. The district will keep families up to date with new information as the situation evolves.

Public health officials advise that schools continue with normally recommended measures to prevent the spread of viruses in schools. Schools will be providing reminders and lessons on good hand and respiratory hygiene.
There are also simple things you can do to help your family and others stay healthy. Please take some time in the coming days to review the following with your student:

li.a: Wash hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds.

ul.li: Use a hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available.
Avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth with unwashed hands.
Practice good respiratory hygiene, covering coughs and sneezes with your elbow or a tissue that is then thrown away, followed by washing your hands.
Students with a fever should stay home from school.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces using a regular household cleaning spray or wipes.
Get your annual flu vaccine (to protect against flu).
